info.game_comments:
2003 College Championship semifinal game 2.
From Yale University.

(1, 1).clue: Under Kansas law, this document shall be conspicuously posted in your primary work station

(2, 1).clue: There are "Two Scoops of Raisins" in this company's Raisin Bran

(3, 1).clue: A 1928 campaign slogan promised this "in every pot and a car in every garage"

(4, 1).clue: 1977:"A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away"

(5, 1).clue: Bach was born in 1685 in Thuringen in what is now this country

(6, 1).clue: The Holy Bible is made up of the "Old" & "New" ones

(1, 2).clue: That the American College of Hairstyling requires 60 hours of training in this shouldn't have you in a lather

(2, 2).clue: Raisins came to the West in the 11th C. when knights brought them back after these military expeditions

(3, 2).clue: Years of political rivalry led to the July 11, 1804 duel between these 2 men

(5, 2).clue: A popular Bach cantata tells the story of a father's fear that his daughter is addicted to this morning drink

(6, 2).clue: Gouverneur Morris was responsible for much of the wording of this in 1787

(1, 3).clue: A barber in training might want to pick up a supply of styptic pencils; they help staunch this

(2, 3).clue: With about half of the world's supply grown there, this U.S. state leads the world in raisin production

(3, 3).clue: In 1776 this silversmith set up a mill to make gunpowder after the colonists ran out of it at Bunker Hill

(4, 3).clue: 2003:"There are 3.7 trillion fish in the ocean, they're looking for one"

(5, 3).clue: In his day, it's the instrument Bach was best known for playing; he was an expert on its design & construction

(6, 3).clue: While not an M.D., this person can still diagnose eye problems & prescribe glasses

(1, 4).clue: Brands of these include Hask, Jerris & Lucky Tiger; & you don't mix them with gin

(2, 4).clue: This Carthaginian general reportedly gave rations of raisins to his troops when they were crossing the Alps

(3, 4).clue: The Confederate States of America were established in 1861 in this city, the first Confederate capital

(4, 4).clue: 2001:"Power can be held in the smallest of things"
(4, 4).correct response: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring

(5, 4).clue: Bach wrote a well-known set of concertos for Christian Ludwig, the margrave of this region

(6, 4).clue: It's the lever pilots use to control the power & speed of many planes

(1, 5).clue: Marvy's Model 55 one of these has a globe on top & runs about $500 (you might want one when you set up shop)

(2, 5).clue: From the Old French for "Raisins of Corinth", it's what Europeans call some raisins

(3, 5).clue: This leader of the Green Mountain Boys was a champion for the creation of the Green Mountain State

(5, 5).clue: This early 20th C. missionary to Africa was a great admirer of Bach's & often performed his works in concert

(6, 5).clue: To create an opera, you need a composer & this person who writes or adapts the text

(1, 1).clue: After the Arab conquest in the 7th century, the Berbers picked up this religion, but are a bit less orthodox about it

(2, 1).clue: Natascha Badmann was a champ in the duathlon (running & biking), then added this sport to triumph in the triathlon

(3, 1).clue: In 1931 this Indian pacifist signed an agreement with Lord Irwin to stop his campaign of civil disobedience

(5, 1).clue: Thomas Hardy novel in which Jude Fawley lives to see all his childhood hopes & dreams dashed...then he dies

(6, 1).clue: This word for stealing livestock also refers to a soft sound made by leaves

(1, 2).clue: Berbers account for a quarter of Algeria's population & a third of this neighbor to the west

(3, 2).clue: While the Huang He is called "China's Sorrow", this river is "China's Fortune"

(5, 2).clue: Hardy novel in which the title heroine makes a series of unfortunate decisions...then she's hanged

(6, 2).clue: Also known as Cos lettuce, it's traditionally found in Caesar salad

(1, 3).clue: The North African area that was home to pirates was called this after the Berbers

(2, 3).clue: When her baby arrived early in June 2003, the father, also a sprinter, said, "I didn't expect him to be this fast"

(3, 3).clue: Russia claims & occupies all of the Kuril Islands, but this country lays claim to some of the southern islands

(5, 3).clue: Hardy novel in which Clym returns to the heath where his mom dies from a snakebite... then his wife drowns

(6, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew at the Oklahoma City National Memorial)  A place for quiet thoughts, this kind of pool here in Oklahoma City shares its name with one near the Lincoln Memorial

(1, 4).clue: Some say the Berbers were the first to breed these from polecats they captured in Spain

(6, 4).clue: This Icelandic city's marathon has had a good run; it had its 20th anniversary in 2003

(3, 5).clue: Tibetans practice this form of Buddhism whose chief sect is the Yellow Hat

(6, 5).clue: From a Latin word for "reddish", it's another name for German measles

(0, 0).clue: The name of this type of reference book comes from the Greek for "circle of instruction"
